One of the ﬁrst rules to observe with this book is that the solutions to each problem are presented in three different formats, with answers presented in different ways if required and that answers should not normally be confused or taken in any particular order. This is to illustrate the many different ways of solving problems and the many alternative and acceptable answers. You can read the solutions in an ordinary way as a text book as many people prefer. On the other hand, you may also be interested to see some diagrams to illustrate the problems or the way the problems are presented. These are also available in solutions. You should note that some questions have a solution to the left and a solution to the right with different answers that should not be confused or taken in any particular order. Problem solving questions are also sometimes written over a page or across a pair of pages and often contain partial answers for which you are only told that they are incorrect and asked to indicate why. In this book, we follow the same format as is established by Mathematics at Work by Robert Israel. It includes questions designed to test your problem-solving abilities. These problems, or exercises as we sometimes call them, vary from easy to very difﬁcult. The format here is that the solutions are presented in three different ways: diagrams, numbers or words, and you must determine whether the answers are correct or not. You should ﬁnd the solutions informative. As with questions and solutions given in other books, the answers have not been published to protect the integrity of the examination process. The solutions give you a further opportunity to solve problems. Some may be answered in two different ways while some may require a certain amount of intuition and good judgement to be acceptable or even correct. The Pythagorean Theorem is not just for 2-dimensional triangles. It also works in 2-dimensional circles, right? If I double my distance from a point on a line or circle, will my distance from that centre be the square of my half the initial distance?
If I double my distance in a circle I'd still be close to the centre of the circle, because the radius is increasing, but the distance from the centre doesn't increase by a square of the distance. This could mean I'd be close to the circumference, but not by a square of the distance from the centre, right?
The Pythagorean Theorem is not just for 2-dimensional triangles.
The Pythagorean Theorem states that
c2 = a2 + b2 where a is the longer side and b the shorter side of a triangle.
It does not involve centers of the triangle.
It only works to form right angles (90 degrees).
If I double my distance from a point on a line or circle, will my distance from that centre be the square of my half the initial distance?
I don't know your definitions for "distance" and "centre" in this context.
In either case the answer is No.
I agree, I wasn't stating the pythagorean theorem for the purposes of a question on a different site, only to state that the theorem was valid in two dimensions. I also agree that in a circle, I wouldn't be doubling my distance but only the length of my distance.
The answer given by @WingedPanther to the original question was a "Yes ... in some sense" but I'd like to know what the "sense" is.
If we doubled our distance, we could be very close to the circumference, or very far away but in both situations, we would not be doubling the length of our original distance away from the centre of the circle.
No, but it might be the square of the distance from the centre minus half the distance from the centre....
@GraemeCLARK Your first question is whether the square of the distance from the circumference will increase by a factor of two. (Hence the initial distance being the square root of the length of the distance of the circumference.)
@GraemeCLARK, the 2-dimensional pythagorean theorem holds in the special case that you've indicated above and stated in a comment which implies the same meaning.

But you're wrong about what I think is the solution (you haven't commented on the 2nd diagram:
If the algebraic expression 2x2 + x2 represents the sum of the squares from x1 until x2, then the square root (which is not necessarily a whole number!) is still just the sum of squares until the same square is a multiple of (the squared root of:) twice the sum of squares. This is represented by the diagram on the right
I can accept some mistakes in some of your answers but you're only being inconsistent if this is what you're teaching your students
The arithmetic mean of a square is the square root of the sum of the squares.
The geometric mean of a pair of similar squares is the square root of their sides.
The 2-dimensional pythagorean theorem applies to similar squares by applying to the squared sides and not the sides themselves.
For example, in similar right triangles, the angle at the hypotenuse is equal to two right angles.
Here's the diagram with my explanation:
The sum of a geometric series is the square root of 1 less the ratio.
So the sum of the geometric series
(1 - 0.1)^n
with an = n is the square root of 1 - 0.1^(n).
The sum of the geometric series is the geometric mean.
The arithmetic mean of the geometric series is 1 + 0.1 + 0.1^2 + 0.1^3 + + + + 0.1^n.
Note that the arithmetic mean of the geometric series with a = n is the square root of 2 n when a = n, and is not the geometric mean!
Here's a graph showing the progression of geometric series. The graph shows the square of each of the first seven multiplied by the next seven by the end of the geometric series.

Ask to me about my work and you will find that it is a matter of common observation, and it may be understood as easily as are any of the other phenomena of the realm of sense which surrounds us. There is this difference, however, between such things and the mind to which we give the name of Reason, in that it is not so easy to convince men who think they are Reason's disciples that they have not the remotest understanding of it. The reasons why this is so are many and complicated, but chief amongst them is to be found the fact that the Reasoning faculty, like all other faculties of the body, can be cultivated and become a strong and efficient ally, or by abuse or neglect it can lose its usefulness and become positively harmful. The Reason in some people is weak and cannot distinguish between what ought to be done and what ought not to be, and it is not only unable to enforce the rule that all must follow but, since it has no means of enforcing anything, must inevitably succumb, a helpless slave, once it is opposed by what is strong. There are men who, having failed to obey the will of another person, have yielded to reason and obeyed Reason, which is all the more to their credit; for as the Reasoning faculty has within it all that we know and all that may be known, it can be accepted that the Reasoning intellect itself will be weakened as long as it does not receive all that we ought to give it in order to make it strong. Reason cannot prevail where the rule of the intellect is absent.
And this brings me to my first general observation, concerning the origin of the two kinds of reason, which may be taken to be the most elementary kind of Reason, and that which is so-called philosophical Reason. These two, which arise from Reason, must be distinguished from a third faculty, which is derived from Desire. For if the Reasoning Intellect is sometimes overcome by Reason, even though the Reasoning faculty be weak, the Desiring faculty is always subject to Reason; and so it can be said the latter is the most powerful of the three. It is because of this that those who wish to use reason wisely must first learn to know that one of the two kinds of reasoning is more effective and appropriate than the other. When one of these is used, what it produces will be reason, but when the other is used it will always produce something quite different from that.

The first sort of reasoning which is, properly speaking, the Reasoning faculty is that which arises by the light of Nature, or which is to be called Natural (though the name may be inappropriate in some respects). That is what I have called the Natural Intellect, and it derives its knowledge from the light of Nature given by the Creator so that it may know things which must be known and which can be made known only by Reason and not by experimentation. I say, then, that this is the way in which things may be learned, but how this is brought about will be a matter for our discussion as we go on dealing with this subject, and we shall see what this is like. It should be kept in mind, however, that the way of knowing things through experimentation or reasoning is entirely different in one kind of reasoning than in the other. And so there is a difference between how it would be known what is or is not a syllogism; while it may be known in the one way it cannot be known in the other, and for the reason that they are not in the same relation to one another.
So the first of the three ways of attaining knowledge is this, namely, that which involves the Reasoning faculty when one is investigating the mind and investigating the reasonings of mind, or when it is investigating the nature of the mind itself. That there is a difference in the knowing power that these two ways involve has already been said, because when one is dealing with the natural light of reason we are not dealing with mind but with matter; and what we have been studying here is the way in which the mind knows itself. The other kind of knowing involves the Reasoning faculty, and therefore we are concerned here chiefly with the way in which the mind reasons as a means of knowing the things of the mind; and for this reason, the kind of knowing that involves experimentation differs from that in which one simply observes the things of the mind and the things of Nature by reasoning. For what we are discussing here is this kind of knowing, whereas what we are not discussing is the knowing that is concerned with the thing discovered by experimentation. We are speaking of that kind which involves the Reasoning faculty in its operation, and this is concerned with things which are in the mind; this is the kind of thing with which we must be concerned.
The first kind of knowing that we are discussing is that of the mind by the Reasoning faculty; and I have said that this may be known because mind is reasonable by the light of Reason (and not through experience). That mind may be reasonable in this way has already been shown, but we are now studying the things of mind and not those discovered by experiment. Now it is this kind of mind, and this kind of thing, that will always be found to be reasonable; and therefore such a thing as the knowledge of mind cannot be called knowledge of the subject but of the reason which is within that subject.
Reasoning of the mind deals with the things which are within the mind by its own nature as a rational being. The mind knows itself by this kind of reason; and it is with this kind of mind and this kind of reason by which we now proceed to discuss the Reasoning Intellect.
#7675 by Eodnhoj7 » Tue Nov 07, 2017 12:39 am
In all its movements, then, the Reasoning faculty is a thing of Nature; for it is moved by what is in Nature to follow any particular way of reasoning. We have said that it is moved by the light of Reason to follow this way of proceeding, while it follows the way of its own nature if it is moved by any other cause. And if the way in which there is movement is of the mind, it is by means of the mind that the Reasoning Intellect operates, in that it operates according to the will of the rational being; and if the movement is not of the mind but of another body, then the Reasoning Intellect can move only with the movement of the other body; and such a process would involve the Reasoning faculty itself in the movement of the other body. And so the Reasoning faculty cannot be in accord with its own nature unless it is moved in accord with its own nature, in which case it must move its body according to the rule of its nature.
This process has been explained as being a movement of the Reasoning faculty; but if I mean that the Reasoning faculty moves itself according to its own nature then the same thing can be asserted of the movement with which the Reasoning Intellect moves itself; and it is moved by this nature itself by means of a movement by the rational being itself.
If it is said that this Reasoning faculty moves itself of itself, it is of itself and not of its nature, in that it is so moved of its own nature. And if this is true of the nature of the Reasoning faculty itself, it is also true of its being moved by that of its nature, namely, by its movement of the Reasoning faculty. This reason, then, will be different from that which causes the Reasoning faculty to be moved by other movements of the mind.
#7676 by Eodnhoj7 » Tue Nov 07, 2017 2:44 pm
In short, one may say (and properly so) that this Reasoning faculty is not moved according to its own nature unless it is moved by that which is natural to it, in that it is its own nature and the movement itself moves the Reasoning faculty according to its own nature.
#7677 by Eodnhoj7 » Wed Nov 08, 2017 1:14 pm
The Reasoning faculty is not moved by any other way of reasoning than that which the Reasoning faculty itself reasons naturally. But this is not the case if the Reasoning faculty moves itself by means of Reasoning other than itself (and this being the case is a part of what the Reasoning faculty is, for if it is not so moved but moves itself by the power of its own nature, it will be so moved, in that it moves itself and not something which it does not itself move by another movement). In this respect it is not so moved by that which Reasoning itself moves it by means of Reasoning other than itself.
But the Reasoning faculty moves itself by means of Reasoning other than itself. And therefore this Reasoning Intellect, which is of the Reasoning faculty itself, is not moved by what it moves of itself, but by what also it moves of itself; and so it is not moved by that which it moves of itself, but by the movement itself, according to the nature of the Reasoning Intellect itself.
So what I say is this, and it is true of itself: the Reasoning Intellect is not moved naturally by that which it moves of itself, but is moved by that which it moves by natural Reasoning (for what it moves of itself moves by that which moves of itself, and so it is Reasoning Intellect itself which moves of itself).
So in this respect, I can say that the Reasoning faculty is in accord in its knowing (of that which the Reasoning Intellect knows through the Reasoning Intellect itself by means of Reasoning itself).
And even if the Reasoning Intellect is not moved by the movement of Itself, it is not moved by that which it moves of itself, but by that which it moves of itself in accordance (for what it moves of itself moves by that which moves of it self, and so it is reasoninection intellect itself which moves of it), self, so it is not moved by that w it moves of it, but by that which it moves of itself, and so it is not moved by witch moves of it, but by that wb it is not moved by thatwhich moves of it, but by that which moves of it)

An interesting conjecture is Goldbach's Conjecture (not to be confused with Goldbach's other conjecture), which is the conjecture that every even number greater than 2 can be written as the sum of exactly two primes. This is a very open problem. Currently very few known non-trivial cases of this, and many conjectures that are probably false.
A related problem is whether there is a function $f(\mbox{even}) = 1$ and $\mbox{$f$}(2)=1$. Goldbach's conjecture implies the existence of such a function. It is believed to be untrue, but there is currently no proof of it.
Another unsolved problem is the Collatz conjecture, which asks whether every positive integer is ultimately periodic, and if so what are all the periods. There are some partial results saying that every number can, in principle, be reduced to a negative number, and that some number like 101 has a period, but no proof that every number is ultimately periodic, nor what the period might be if it exists.
Curtis LopezCurtis Lopez

On the contrary of the Axiom of Choice, the Principle of Plenitude (it is not about choice of elements of a set) states that " every non-empty set has a maximal element"; its converse, namely that " Every set has a maximal element", is known as the Plenitude Principle, which, together with the Axiom of Sets can be considered as the basis for Zermelo-Franel set theory.
The Plenitude Principle is an Axiom, one of the weakest in the Zermelo-Franel system, and one of the axioms usually considered as true (other ones can be classed as theorems, etc.).
I think it is a rather surprising and interesting fact that the Plenitude Principle can be deduced from the Axiom of Sets alone.

On a related note, it isn't known if the constructible universe (the set of all constructable sets) is a regular cardinal or not. There are some strong reasons to believe it is a regular cardinale, but no actual proof.
A (not especially rigorous) idea is that an uncountable regular cardinal should be able to "fit" every possible finite uncountable sequence of "reasonable" ordinals (e.g. the continuum plus a big cofinal interval). Given this, it's reasonable to expect the constructible universe to be uncountable.
$\begingroup$ But in the constructible universe we have a model of ZFC, doesn't that model of ZFC have a regular cardinal which is the cardinality of the continuum? (I suppose if it wasn't then we would have set theoretic inconsistency.) So it seems plausible that the constructible universe is a regular cardinal, which means there must be a proof that the constructible universe is not countably infinite, or else ZFC is inconsistent. $\endgroup$
$\begingroup$ You're right, the continuum model of ZFC is uncountable, even if it does not contain a regular cardinal (a standard argument is that V-large=cofinally dense in c, hence countable and thus does not contain a regular cardinal).. So I'm not sure how large the cardinality of the continuum model of the constructible universe must be, that's good question for you to ask (and it is open). $\endgroup$
$\begingroup$ I've added this point to the answer. $\endgroup$
The existence of large cardinal implies that ZFC cannot be consistent. In particular, the following proposition is true in ZFC:
For any two non-isomorphic uncountable cardinals $\alpha$ and $\beta$, there exists an infinite cardinal $\delta$ such that $\vert\delta\vert<\alpha$ and $\delta=H(\alpha)$
See "A solution of the continuum implication problem" by Martin H. K. Baer, 1982.
$\begingroup$ I think Martin H. K. Baer's paper was about the existence of a cardinal between two given cardinals, without additional assumptions. At least that's what I thought from the abstract. $\endgroup$
$\begingroup$ @Martin.Sleziak: You are right. After reading the paper carefully, it is clear that the assumption is: Given two uncountable cardinals \alpha and \beta there exits an infinite cardinal \delta such that \delta=H(\alpha) and \delta=H(\beta). No assumptions regarding the cardinalities of \alpha and \beta, but this is not explicitly formulated as an assumption! $\endgroup$

A countable elementary submodel of a model of ZF does not exist in a countable model of ZF.
For example, let $C_0 := \omega_1$ with $a_1 = 2$, where $\omega_1$ means the first uncountable ordinal.
Let $M := (C_0, a_1)$, and let $c_0:C_0 \to C_0: x \mapsto 2x$. Let $S := \{x \mid c_0(x) = x\}$. Then $S$ is an equivalence relation on $C_0$ and $S/M$ is a model of ZF that is not the same as $M$.
This shows that there are countable models of ZF in which ZF does not impose countability.
